title: Thursday preview: Sports Direct reports full-year earnings, Fed's Yellen delivers testimony
text:
11.34 0.00 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - Sports Direct is expected on Thursday to post an increase in full-year earnings in line with market consensus. In May, the retailer of sporting goods said underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) would match analysts' forecasts but pre-tax profit and earnings per share would be marginally ahead. 
"Despite the governance-related concerns of the market (reduced disclosure, Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) /Debenhams (Other OTC: DBHSF - news ) stakes, zero hours contracts, USC administration) and a slower than expected progression into Europe, we remain confident that Sports Direct can drive greater profitability from its leading UK position and replicate its successful model across the continent, supporting a substantial long-term growth opportunity," said Numis analyst Andrew Wade in a note issued on Wednesday. 
Numis predicted EBITDA of £379m, compared to the previous year's £331.4m. The brokerage recommended a 'buy' rating on Wednesday. 
Dixons Carphone (LSE: DC.L - news ) also releases its annual results with UBS (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) predicting pre-tax profit of £377.5m, earnings per share of 24.4p and a dividend of 8p. 
The company has reported a strong fourth quarter, driven by the UK, raising its pre-tax profit guidance to "slightly above the opt end of a previously guided range of £355m-£375m. 
"The recent performance in terms of profitable market share gains and new contract wins clearly shows the success of the merger last summer, despite the fact that most of the merger benefits are probably yet to accrue," said UBS analyst Andrew Hughes. 
"Looking ahead, the key focus will likely be on any final comments on the scale and timing of these benefits (both sales and margin related), the shape of the group going forward following the exit from Germany and Holland, and whether the group decides to accelerate the space change programme from a position of P&L and balance sheet strength." Away from companies, Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen will be in the spotlight again on Thursday, which will be the last day of her two days on Capital Hill to discuss monetary policy. Yellen is expected to say that an increase in short-term interest rates is likely to come at some point this year, according to prepared remarks ahead of the testimony. 
She will reiterate the stance she set out on 10 July in a speech in Cleveland, with traders expected to tune into the question and answer session scheduled after her speech.
